Hi Jim,

I concur with Ken and John on this one. In the NN's I have encountered 
elsewhere the inputs are usually 'straight-through' or placeholder nodes 
that don't apply a function for precisely the reasons you stated. Of 
course if you were to normalize the input signals to between -1.0,1.0 
then no information is actually lost and experiments should (I would 
guess)  perform just as well as when no function is used. This is most 
likely what has occured with Derek and Philips experiments, e.g. the XOR 
experiments used inputs of -1,1 and 0.

As for whether using an input layer activation has a benefit, I'm not 
well versed in NN's enough to say yes or no. It may have a benefit for 
some experiments, but on the whole it's more useful to have 
straight-through input nodes and then to normalize the input signals or 
adjust them in some other way before being aplied to the NN and on a 
per-experiment basis.

Colin.
